author: By Christina Jewett
title: Senators Question Califf, the F.D.A. Nominee, on Opioid Crisis and Pandemic Response
description: A Senate panel hearing on Tuesday signaled that Dr. Robert Califf, who briefly led the agency during the Obama administration, had some bipartisan support.
content: A Senate panel on Tuesday intensely questioned Dr. Robert Califf, the nominee for commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, on pressing issues like the coronavirus pandemic, the opioid crisis, his financial ties to the pharmaceutical industry and possible changes in the rules for medications used for abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Omicron is a dress rehearsal for the next pandemic.
description: When scientists discovered the highly mutated Omicron variant of the coronavirus last month, it set off an eerily familiar chain of events.
content: When scientists discovered the highly mutated Omicron variant of the coronavirus last month, it set off an eerily familiar chain of events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Joshua Bellamy, Ex-Jet, Is Sentenced to 3 Years in Covid-19 Aid Scheme
description: Mr. Bellamy obtained a Paycheck Protection Program loan for $1.2 million for his company, Drip Entertainment L.L.C., by using false information, federal prosecutors said.
content: A former wide receiver for the New York Jets who fraudulently obtained more than $1.2 million in Covid-19 relief money and spent tens of thousands of dollars of that on luxury items has been sentenced to more than three years in prison, federal prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: ‘Return of the Jedi’ and ‘The Fellowship of the Ring’ Join National Film Registry
description: Those movies, along with “Selena,” “Wall-E” and “A Nightmare on Elm Street” are among 25 selected by the Librarian of Congress.
content: It’s not just Gollum who thinks a certain ring is precious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Congress Approves $2.5 Trillion Debt Limit Increase, Sending It to Biden
description: The measure would allow the government to continue borrowing to finance its obligations without further action by Congress until after the 2022 midterm elections.
content: WASHINGTON — Congress gave final approval early Wednesday to legislation that would raise the debt ceiling by $2.5 trillion, moving over nearly unanimous Republican opposition to stave off the threat of a first-ever federal default until at least early 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Azi Paybarah
title: Heavy Rain and Snow Hit California
description: A weather system that has brought mudslides and dangerous driving conditions across the state could linger into Wednesday.
content: A sprawling weather system brought torrential rain and heavy snow across California on Tuesday, a day after wreaking havoc on the northern part of the state, meteorologists said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judith Newman
title: Want Something Done Right? Do It Yourself. These Books Can Help.
description: From decorating to beauty projects to canine costumes, these how-to guides may inspire you to take matters into your own hands.
content: Sometime during the pandemic I began getting emails from a D.I.Y. site called Hometalk. Mine is not a do-it-yourself household, and won’t be until they come up with D.I.Y. liposuction. But every day there is this email, a little ray of hope that I will become the kind of person who could make a pretty Christmas tree with 10 flattened toilet paper tubes or a “fun cork Christmas gang” courtesy of my weekly chardonnay consumption. It could happen! I love these projects and their valuable life lesson: You are not truly living without pipe cleaners, Styrofoam cubes and a bedazzler.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: Phillip Adams Had Severe C.T.E. at the Time of Shootings
description: A neuropathologist found an “unusually severe” form of the brain disease in the 32-year-old former N.F.L. player who killed six people in April before shooting himself.
content: The posthumous brain examination of Phillip Adams, a 32-year-old retired journeyman N.F.L. player who shot and killed six people before dying by suicide in April, revealed that he had an “unusually severe” form of C.T.E., a degenerative brain disease found in athletes and others with a history of repeated hits to the head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: A Witty Mastermind of Les Ballets Trockadero Comes Home
description: Peter Anastos returns to the comedic troupe he helped found for “Nightcrawlers,” a Jerome Robbins sendup at the Joyce Theater.
content: It was 1976, and the Jerome Robbins ballet “Dances at a Gathering” was still a hit, seven years after its premiere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Wirecutter Union reaches a deal with The New York Times Company.
description: The contract, which the union’s members will vote on, includes immediate average wage increases of about $5,000 and 3 percent raises for each year of the deal, which runs through February 2024.
content: Union members at Wirecutter, the product recommendation website owned by The New York Times Company, said on Tuesday that they had reached a deal on their first contract after two years of negotiations that were at times contentious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Cuomo Is Ordered to Forfeit Earnings From $5.1 Million Book Deal
description: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo received authorization to write the book under false pretenses, the board had previously ruled.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — A New York State ethics board ordered former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Tuesday to turn over millions of dollars in profits from his coronavirus pandemic memoir, giving him 30 days to comply.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Comments on the ‘Slides of Sedition’
description: Colbert couldn’t believe Congress is currently investigating a 38-page PowerPoint document detailing plans to overturn the 2020 election.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Casey Quackenbush
title: Why My Family Loves Giving Leftover Junk
description: If you’re looking for an antidote to the most expensive time of year, consider giving them the gift of laughter with a “rewrap.”
content: On Christmas morning last year, most of the gifts under my family’s tree were adorned in filmy old drugstore wrapping paper: green plaid, snowflakes, Santa Claus. So when my mom passed me a pristine white rectangular box, I got excited. It stood out from the Amazon Prime boxes in its impeccable condition, and it was heavy too. My excitement only mounted when I saw my mom’s grin, which stretched to her ears. I undid the magnetic seal to discover a bottle of sparkling wine, coated in a tacky gold glitter, along with two flutes (one broken) and a confetti popper — a great gift for a New Year’s Eve party I had no plans to attend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Rams Remind Cardinals There’s Another Team in the N.F.C. West
description: Despite missing multiple players to Covid, Los Angeles and its veteran stars knocked off the division leaders.
content: Our NFL playoffs calculator has an up-to-date look at the latest playoff picture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Lazar
title: Are Creative Types Inherently Wicked? Ask Tom Bissell.
description: The stories in Bissell’s stylish new collection, “Creative Types,” feature vigilantes, bullies and other characters with questionable moral compasses.
content: CREATIVE TYPESAnd Other StoriesBy Tom Bissell
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: The Ankler, a hit Hollywood newsletter, charts an expansion.
description: Janice Min, a leading editor, joins forces with the writer Richard Rushfield.
content: Janice Min, a media executive in Los Angeles, is joining forces with Richard Rushfield, a show-business columnist, to start a new media business that will be spun off from his popular subscription newsletter, The Ankler.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Fondren
title: Sandra Lindsay reflects on her vaccine, 1 year later: ‘I felt like it was my civic duty.’
description: “I look back now with a lot of pride, knowing that I did my part,” said Ms. Lindsay, the New York-area nurse who was the first person in the United States to get vaccinated outside a clinical trial.
content: If ever again given the opportunity to be the first person in the United States to receive a coronavirus vaccine, even while knowing what comes with being the first to do anything, Sandra Lindsay said she would do it all over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Charles R. Morris, Iconoclastic Author on Economics, Dies at 82
description: Resisting ideological labels, experienced in government and banking, he critiqued policymakers’ “good intentions” and the costs of health care and forecast the 2008 financial crisis.
content: Charles R. Morris, a former government official, banker and self-taught historian of economics who as a prolific, iconoclastic author challenged conventional political and economic pieties, died on Monday in Hampton, N.H. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Three were jailed in Greece after a principal was handcuffed over virus measures.
description: Police said a group of people handcuffed the principal on Friday and drove him to a local precinct, suggesting that officers arrest him for enforcing Covid measures.
content: The authorities in northern Greece have jailed three people pending trial and placed restrictions on eight others over an attack on a school principal related to coronavirus restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: House Seeks Contempt Charge Against Meadows in Jan. 6 Inquiry
description: The former White House chief of staff previously provided the committee with thousands of pages of documents, including text messages he received on Jan. 6.
content: WASHINGTON — The House voted on Tuesday night to recommend holding Mark Meadows, who served as chief of staff to former President Donald J. Trump, in criminal contempt of Congress for refusing to cooperate with its investigation into the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, escalating a legal battle against a potentially crucial witness in a widening inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Amtrak Worker Sold Railroad Equipment for Years to Line His Pockets, U.S. Says
description: Jose Rodriquez, 49, of Brick, N.J., pleaded guilty to mail fraud on Monday. Prosecutors said he obtained 114 chain saws for the railroad service, but sold them for profit.
content: For more than seven years, the authorities said, Jose Rodriguez of Brick, N.J., a senior engineer at Amtrak, obtained more than 100 chain saws and hundreds of chain saw parts from the railroad, claiming he needed them for various service projects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly
title: Firms Push to Make Birth-Control Pills Available Without Prescriptions
description: Two drugmakers have been mired for years in the pre-application phase of getting F.D.A. approval for over-the-counter use.
content: A few years ago, after learning she had high blood pressure, Shannon Connell-Robichaud asked her doctor to switch her birth-control pill prescription. She had read that the pill she had been prescribed put people around her age with that condition at high risk of a stroke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Porter
title: Worried About Inflation? Here’s What That May Reveal About You.
description: Age, region, education and income all influence what people think consumer prices will be a few years from now. And that creates a policy puzzle.
content: Who is worried about inflation? Older Americans, for sure; the young, not so much.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Vicente Fernández Knew His Way Around Your Broken Heart
description: First breakups. Final goodbyes. For generations, Mr. Fernández, who died on Sunday, provided a soundtrack for moments of anguish and heartache, and a pathway to healing.
content: After four years of dating, this is what it came to for Art Castillo: sitting alone in his blue truck in Waco, Texas, listening to his girlfriend on speaker. Long distance wasn’t working, she told him. She had found another man. The relationship was over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Little Bit of Time
description: Tao Platt makes his New York Times debut.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to the constructor Tao Platt on making his New York Times Crossword debut with this impressive Tuesday puzzle. It’s rare to see so much thematic content (and secret grid art!) in an early-week puzzle, but Mr. Platt has pulled it off admirably.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Pfizer, Antarctica, James Webb Telescope: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Sears, Struggling to Sell Goods, Markets a Valuable Asset: Real Estate
description: Many former stores are being overhauled for new retailers, but developers are installing high-end apartments, cutting-edge classrooms and even labs at sites around the country.
content: Shoppers may no longer come in droves for wrenches, watches or washing machines. But Sears, the once-ubiquitous department store that has been battered by the growth of e-commerce, may have one last thing of value to market: its own buildings.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 14, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Dec. 14, 2021.
content: An article on Nov. 17 about Refaat Alareer, a Palestinian professor who includes a discussion of Israeli poetry in his literature classes, gave an inaccurate portrayal of the professor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Todd Gregory
title: Massachusetts joins other states in distributing free at-home tests.
description: Massachusetts secured more than two million rapid at-home tests that would be delivered to 102 towns with high poverty rates.
content: Massachusetts said on Monday that it would offer free at-home coronavirus tests to some of its residents, joining several other states around the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Officer Is Charged With Protecting Prostitution Ring in Exchange for Sex
description: Prosecutors say Wayne Peiffer, a police officer in Brewster, N.Y., had women from sex-trafficking and prostitution rings brought to him at the police station.
content: In December 2017, Wayne Peiffer, a police officer in Brewster, N.Y., received a text message from a Queens man who prosecutors say worked as a driver for a prostitution ring. For months, the man — identified in court documents as Cristian Noe Godinez — had been driving women to the Putnam County village, near the Connecticut border, to perform sex acts on Officer Peiffer, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: Proud Boys Regroup, Focusing on School Boards and Town Councils
description: The far-right nationalist group has become increasingly active at school board meetings and town council gatherings across the country.
content: They showed up last month outside the school board building in Beloit, Wis., to protest school masking requirements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Timeless Wisdom for Leading a Life of Love, Friendship and Learning
description: The ethicist Leon Kass discusses the ingredients for a meaningful life.
content: “Today, we are supercompetent when it comes to efficiency, utility, speed, convenience, and getting ahead in the world; but we are at a loss concerning what it’s all for,” Leon Kass writes in his 2017 book “Leading a Worthy Life.” “This lack of cultural and moral confidence about what makes a life worth living is perhaps the deepest curse of living in our interesting time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Monika Pronczuk
title: E.U. Proposes Changes That Would Chip Away at Borderless Model
description: The plan would institutionalize internal border controls to respond to emergencies, suspending some protections for asylum seekers.
content: BRUSSELS — Bruised by haphazard pandemic border controls and an ongoing crisis with Belarus over migrants on its eastern frontier, the European Union is proposing changes that could chip away at one of its crowning achievements — the unfettered movement of people within the bloc.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Conservatives Abandon Johnson Over New Covid Rules
description: A record number of Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s fellow party members voted against his plan for Covid certificates. But the plan passed with the help of the opposition.
content: LONDON — The British government estimates that 200,000 people a day are being infected with the latest coronavirus variant, Omicron. Yet in Parliament on Tuesday, a record number of Conservative lawmakers voted against one of Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s key measures to quell the outbreak, a policy of vaccine certification to enter nightclubs and places with large crowds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: debris
description: This word has appeared in 452 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: What Is Your Choice for Word of the Year?
description: Tell us what word you think best reflects “the ethos, mood or preoccupations” of 2021.
content: What one word best sums up everything that happened in 2021?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: A Teen Sensation Grows Up
description: Everyone seemed to love Chloe Kim when she was a snowboarding prodigy on her way to an Olympic gold medal. When she saw the downside of fame, she stepped back and built a life beyond the halfpipe.
content: LOS ANGELES — The American snowboarder Chloe Kim was 17 years old at the last Winter Olympics, in Pyeongchang, where she gleefully stomped her way to a gold medal in the halfpipe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Filipovic
title: The Anti-Abortion Movement Could Reduce Abortions if It Wanted To
description: Contraception would reduce abortions. Why doesn’t the anti-abortion movement promote it?
content: Often an abortion happens because a woman is pregnant when she didn’t intend to be. It is true that some women terminate wanted but doomed pregnancies and others face serious health complications. But if abortion opponents are serious about decreasing the need for abortion instead of simply punishing women and doctors, they should be rallying around contraception access. Instead, they’re largely standing in the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Kentucky on My Mind
description: On states that bite the hand that feeds them.
content: On Friday, a devastating swarm of tornadoes swept through Kentucky. The state’s leading figures appealed for federal aid, which was promptly granted — and rightly so. Helping people and communities in need is what nations are supposed to do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Illnesses tied to the Omicron variant may be milder, a preliminary study suggests.
description: The findings, which also show that the new variant partly dodges the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, are based on only three weeks of data. Epidemiologists cautioned that the full picture is still emerging.
content: JOHANNESBURG — An early study of coronavirus test results in South Africa suggests that, so far, patients infected with the Omicron variant may be hospitalized less often than patients infected with earlier versions of the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Santa Claus’s Real Estate Is Booming
description: Is it any surprise that places where it’s ‘Christmas all the time’ have been attracting a record number of buyers during the pandemic?
content: Nancy Schwab loves Christmas. Really, really loves Christmas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Neville
title: Fires, Landslides, Lack of Snow: The Ski Industry Girds for Battle
description: From firestorms in California’s Tahoe region to melting glaciers in the Alps, ski areas face a daunting array of environmental threats. Here’s what some resorts are doing.
content: From the top of an intermediate ski slope called Ridge Run at Lake Tahoe’s Heavenly resort, Bryan Hickman knew what was at stake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jaime Lowe
title: How to Hang a Gallery Wall
description: Start at the bottom, in the center, and work up and out. Don’t center the biggest piece of art.
content: “I love trying to find pieces that dialogue — either in terms of textures, in terms of colors, in terms of what is represented — so that they feel connected with each other,” says Anne-Laure Lemaitre, an art adviser who has recently curated shows at Swivel Gallery and Kapp Kapp in New York. “You can have an abstract piece that is super-textured and a very precise drawing, but they both have something that connects them, like green and orange tones.” Or two portraits might be very different in feel, yet “they kind of talk to each other.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Michael Gargiulo Dies at 95; Documented the Moscow ‘Kitchen Debate’
description: Sent to the Soviet Union in 1959 to promote color television, he ended up taping what he later called a “turning point” in U.S.-Soviet relations.
content: Michael Gargiulo, an Emmy Award-winning television director and producer who immortalized the impromptu 1959 “kitchen debate” between Vice President Richard M. Nixon and the Soviet leader, Nikita S. Khrushchev, in Moscow, died on Nov. 30 at his home in Manhattan. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan and Robin Stein
title: Facing Covid Spike, N.F.L. Mandates Boosters, but Stops Short on Testing
description: The league will require boosters for coaches and some team personnel after a single-day high in positive tests among players. But the players’ union has argued that daily testing should resume.
content: The Los Angeles Rams football team had five players test positive for the coronavirus ahead of Monday night’s game against Arizona. In Detroit, the Lions met remotely after reporting eight players with the virus as many days. And a Washington Football team employee reported what may be the league’s first case of the Omicron variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Ronen Bergman and Helene Cooper
title: Israel Finds Planes That Could Be Key to a Strike on Iran Badly Back-Ordered
description: The United States told Israel it was unlikely to deliver refueling tankers before 2024, amid tensions between the two nations over how to deal with Iran’s nuclear program.
content: WASHINGTON — Israel asked the Biden administration last week to speed up the delivery of refueling tankers that could prove critical to striking Iran’s nuclear facilities, but it was told that the aircraft were back-ordered and it was unlikely that its first one would be ready until late 2024, according to U.S. and Israeli officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Linda McAlister, Philosopher and Founder of Feminist Journal, Dies at 82
description: She was among a collective of philosophy professors who started Hypatia, the first major scholarly publication to view the discipline from a feminist lens.
content: Linda Lopez McAlister, a philosophy and women’s studies professor and a founder of Hypatia, a feminist journal that was the first major publication of its kind, died on Nov. 9 at her home in Albuquerque. She was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Daniel Guillemette, Austin Mitchell, Rob Szypko, Chelsea Daniel, Paige Cowett, Lisa Chow, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Why Was Haiti’s President Assassinated?
description: An investigation into the killing of the Caribbean nation’s leader points to corruption and drug trafficking at the highest levels of government.
content: In July, a group of men stormed the presidential compound in Haiti and assassinated the country’s president, Jovenel Moïse. Months later, the case remains unresolved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘In Kentucky, Tallying the Grim Scale of Destruction’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about the impact of the tornadoes that tore through a six-state area last week. Then they will reflect on the power of community, and consider ways to help.
content: Featured Article: “In Kentucky, Tallying the Grim Scale of Destruction”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordan Allen and Miles McKinley
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $6.5 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Sui-Lee Wee
title: Blinken, in Indonesia, Stresses Soft Power to Counter China
description: The U.S. secretary of state seeks to make the case that the United States is a better bet as a partner than China, even if it’s not spending so lavishly in the region.
content: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Downplaying direct confrontation between the United States and China, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken on Tuesday pledged to strengthen relations with Indo-Pacific nations through billions of dollars in American investment and aid and, in doing so, counter Beijing’s regional pull.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: David Brooks Interviews Leon Kass for ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
description: A conversation with the ethicist.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest hosted by David Brooks and featuring Leon Kass. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harold Isaac and Oscar Lopez
title: Fuel Tanker Explodes in Haiti, Killing More Than 60
description: Scores more were injured in the blast, the latest tragedy to hit a country that has been rocked by political violence, natural disasters, poverty and hunger.
content: CAP-HAÏTIEN, Haiti — More than 60 people were killed and scores more were wounded early Tuesday when a truck carrying gasoline exploded in northern Haiti, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Man Exonerated in Malcolm X Murder Files Lawsuit Against New York State
description: Muhammad A. Aziz filed the claim on Tuesday, along with a notice seeking a settlement with the city, for the toll that being “unjustly branded as a convicted murderer” for 55 years took on his life.
content: Standing in a Manhattan courtroom last month, Muhammad A. Aziz lamented the miscarriage of justice that had wrongly labeled him one of Malcolm X’s killers for more than five decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Liu
title: A second Omicron case in China raises the prospect of stricter controls.
description: Though both Omicron cases were quarantined upon arrival, a small outbreak in a building where one man was quarantining highlights how difficult it may be to control the new variant.
content: For the second straight day, China announced it had found a new case of the Omicron variant in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Amtrak temporarily drops its vaccine mandate, avoiding cuts to service.
description: The shift in policy means that Amtrak officials no longer anticipate cuts to service next month.
content: Amtrak has temporarily dropped its mandate for all employees to be vaccinated against Covid-19, a requirement that the rail service had said would likely result in cuts to service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Toyota, lagging rivals, outlines plans to expand sales of electric vehicles.
description: The company’s Lexus brand will only sell electric cars by 2030 in China, Europe and the United States.
content: Toyota, the world’s largest carmaker, belatedly joined the electric vehicle bandwagon on Tuesday, saying it hoped that by the end of the decade battery-powered cars would account for one-third of sales and almost all of the sales of its Lexus luxury brand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Tunisia’s President Promises Vote on Constitution and Sets Election Date
description: President Kais Saied’s announcement dispelled some of the uncertainty Tunisians have endured for months since he shunted aside Parliament in what critics called a soft coup.
content: CAIRO — Tunisia’s president announced on Monday that the country would hold a referendum to amend its Constitution in July, followed by parliamentary elections in December, offering for the first time a concrete path out of the country’s political limbo five months after he seized power in what opponents have called a soft coup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: ‘Wild: A Musical Becoming’ Is Finding Its Footing
description: Idina Menzel and a hummable pop score can’t camouflage the fact that this musical is half-baked. Still, it can make for an enjoyable evening, our critic writes.
content: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — In the 13 years that Diane Paulus has been artistic director of the American Repertory Theater, she has used it as a laboratory for developing new musicals and re-envisioning old ones, then ushering them to Broadway success. “Waitress” and “Jagged Little Pill” had their premieres there; so did Paulus’s staging of “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess” and her revival of “Pippin,” which won her a Tony Award for directing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: ‘Porgy and Bess’ Isn’t Black Opera. It’s American Opera.
description: A touchstone on the path to America’s classical music.
content: I didn’t grow up listening to musical theater cast albums. But one of the family LPs often in rotation was something related: the magnificent soundtrack recording from the 1959 film of “Porgy and Bess.” The movie itself doesn’t really hold up, in part because Sidney Poitier and Dorothy Dandridge are so obviously dubbed when they sing. But that’s irrelevant when listening to the recording, where Robert McFerrin (yes, Bobby’s dad) and Adele Addison sounded like deities, and André Previn’s scoring was superb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Italian Bishop Gives Children Harsh News: There Is No Santa Claus
description: You’ve been lied to, children heard from a bishop, the latest Catholic clergyman to try to take down Santa Claus and consumerism. Many Italians were not pleased.
content: ROME — All that separated the giddy Sicilian school children from meeting Old Saint Nick — arriving on horseback with his long white beard, crimson robe and bag full of gifts — was a Christmas message from the bishop of Noto.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Dream of U.S.-Made Computer Chips
description: Before we invest in making more chips on U.S. soil, we should be asking what we’re trying to achieve.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Patrick McGeehan
title: The ‘Double Whammy’ That Is Slowing New York City’s Job Growth
description: The city has regained fewer than 6 of every 10 jobs it lost since the pandemic began, while the nation as a whole has regained more than 90 percent of lost jobs.
content: Since the start of the year, nearly six million jobs have been added in the United States. The unemployment rate has plummeted to 4.2 percent, close to where it stood before the pandemic. But in New York City, the economy appears to be in a rut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: Duterte Says He Won’t Run for Philippines Senate After All
description: The populist president also promised a peaceful transition of power when his term ends next year.
content: MANILA — President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines on Tuesday ended his bid for a Senate seat in next May’s elections, one day after promising a peaceful transition of power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Workers at two Boston-area Starbucks seek to unionize after a win in Buffalo.
description: The filing with the National Labor Relations Board on Monday could reflect a rising interest in organizing by workers elsewhere.
content: Days after Starbucks employees in Buffalo formed the only union at a company-owned store in the United States, workers at two Boston-area Starbucks filed for union elections with the National Labor Relations Board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: John Cameron Mitchell Finds Joy in Mavis Staples and ‘Veneno’
description: On the eve of concerts celebrating “Hedwig and the Angry Inch,” the writer and performer also shares why “The Gnostic Gospels” feeds his soul.
content: “I haven’t had such a good role since Hedwig,” John Cameron Mitchell said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Big Hospital Chains Drop Vaccine Mandates for Health Workers
description: With the federal requirement in limbo because of legal challenges, some major multistate hospital systems have stopped enforcing their own policies.
content: The legal uncertainty over a federal requirement that the nation’s 17 million health care workers be vaccinated against the coronavirus has led some well-known hospital chains to drop their own mandates — at least temporarily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Marc Tracy
title: Judge Clarifies Order on New York Times Coverage of Project Veritas
description: The decision allows some latitude for reporting until a final ruling is reached. The Times said the order remained “an unconstitutional prior restraint that should be dissolved.”
content: A New York trial court judge on Tuesday issued a clarification in an order that has temporarily prevented The New York Times from seeking out or publishing certain documents related to the conservative group Project Veritas, allowing The Times some latitude to report on the organization until a final ruling is reached.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: A polite F.D.I.C. meeting is followed by scathing statements.
description: A dispute believed by some experts to be part of an effort by Democrats to unseat the chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation board, a Trump appointee, spilled into public view last week.
content: A partisan fight atop a sleepy bank regulator intensified on Tuesday, with Democratic members of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation board saying its Republican chairwoman was subverting the majority’s will.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer and Rebecca Robbins
title: Pfizer’s Covid Pill Works Well, Company Confirms in Final Analysis
description: The treatment, called Paxlovid, is likely to work against Omicron and could be available in the United States before the end of the year.
content: Pfizer announced on Tuesday that its Covid pill was found to stave off severe disease in a key clinical trial and that it is likely to work against the highly mutated Omicron variant of the virus. The results underscore the promise of the treatment, which health officials and doctors are counting on, to ease the burden on hospitals as the United States braces for a mounting fourth wave of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Fed Meets Amid Faster Inflation and Prepares to React
description: The Federal Reserve could announce plans to cut economic support faster, and may signal 2022 rate increases, at its Dec. 14-15 meeting.
content: Federal Reserve officials, worried about rising costs and buoyed by a healing labor market, are pivoting from bolstering the economic recovery to more quickly withdrawing the support that has aided the economy since the pandemic began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Top 10 New York Dishes of 2021
description: As restaurants began to emerge from pandemic lockdowns, Pete Wells was often drawn to superlative versions of classic dishes.
content: Restaurants began the year in darkness. Dining rooms in New York had been closed, again, by order of the governor. Is it any wonder that some of my strongest memories of the year in eating are takeout and delivery dishes? Or that, once restaurants were allowed to serve indoors again in February, the things that tasted best tended to be enduring classics like chicken soup from Eastern Europe and egg rolls from the streets of Saigon? Here are the 10 dishes — in no particular order — that dance in my vision when I close my eyes, all of them taken from establishments in the city that for one reason or another did not make my list of the year’s best new restaurants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Why Do Women Sprout Chin Hairs as They Age?
description: And what’s the best way to remove them?
content: Q: Why do women sprout chin hairs as they age — and what’s the best way to remove them so they don’t grow back darker and thicker?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: The U.S. health secretary hints that more federal funds may be needed to fight an Omicron surge.
description: With the pandemic heading into its third year, much of the money that Congress has allocated for coronavirus response has been spent.
content: Xavier Becerra, the secretary of health and human services, hinted on Tuesday that the Biden administration may need to ask Congress for more money to fight the coronavirus pandemic, depending on the scope and severity of a potential new wave of infections fueled by the Omicron variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum, Ben Protess and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Trump Fraud Inquiry’s Focus: Did He Mislead His Own Accountants?
description: The investigation, by the Manhattan district attorney, is zeroing in on information the former president and his company shared about the value of his assets.
content: As prosecutors in Manhattan weigh whether to charge Donald J. Trump with fraud, they have zeroed in on financial documents that he used to obtain loans and boast about his wealth, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Judge Rules That Congress Can See Trump’s Tax Returns
description: The court dismissed a suit by the former president seeking to bar a House committee from getting his returns, but the judge stayed the ruling to allow time for an appeal.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Tuesday dismissed a lawsuit by Donald J. Trump that sought to block Congress from obtaining his tax returns, ruling that the law gives a House committee chairman broad authority to request them despite Mr. Trump’s status as a former president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: 48 Pieces of Advice From Educators on How to Survive This Challenging Time
description: “You’re not OK. I’m not OK. But that’s OK.”
content: Dealing with mask mandates and health concerns. Facing public scrutiny on how to teach America’s history of racism. Covering colleagues’ classes because there are no substitute teachers. Fighting local book bans. Helping young people cope with mental health issues worsened by the pandemic. This is the reality of many educators in America right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Bogus Bashing of Build Back Better
description: Beware of bad faith, bad logic and bad arithmetic.
content: Build Back Better — the Biden administration’s effort to create a better future for America — is resting on a political knife edge. It’s anyone’s guess whether it will become law. What we do know is that to make it through Congress it will have to weather a perfect storm of bad faith, bad logic and bad arithmetic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Gold
title: Boris Johnson Is in Trouble
description: Britons don’t know whether the prime minister can save himself, let alone Christmas.
content: PENZANCE, England — During the Covid pandemic, we Britons have developed a tabloid obsession with “saving Christmas,” as if it were a beloved pet in danger of being run over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Speed Skydiving
description: Would you ever skydive? Would you want to try speed skydiving?
content: Are you an adrenaline junkie who lives for thrills? If so, would you ever skydive? Did you know about the sport of speed skydiving, which was first developed in 1999?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘A Child I’ll Never Meet’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Walking home, I stopped before a poet for hire and told him I’d had eggs retrieved from my ovaries to create a child I’ll never meet. I expected him to be shocked, but he’d just learned that his mother has other children, so he understood, in a way. He sees strangers with her dimples on the train and wonders. To the child I imagine: I have tried to do something useful, but I’ve also tried to create strangers whose faces I might recognize on the train. I kept the poem in case one of them is ever you. — Kathryn Phelan
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Best Cookbooks of 2021
description: A deep dive into the world of grains, a collection of new cookie classics, unforgettable recipes from Shanghai and more, as tested by New York Cooking and the Food desk.
content: Even those of us who enjoy cooking go through periods where we feel uninspired by our usual rotation of recipes. But nothing snaps you out of a cooking funk quite like the thrill of a brand-new cookbook. Hundreds of cooking guides hit bookshelves this year, each of them a testament to the exciting-if-you-let-it-be art of cooking at home. And some stood out above the rest, with recipes that delivered on ease, creativity and, of course, flavor, while promising a glimpse of the cooks we can be if we just crack open the right book. Here are 14 cookbooks out of the dozens we tested that stood out to the team at New York Times Food and Cooking — not just our editors and columnists, but members of our product, audience and engineering teams as well. Together, these guides represent the best of what cookbooks can be and, yes, they’re guaranteed to inspire. NIKITA RICHARDSON
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Why I Keep Writing About Dive Bars
description: Attracted to the grit, equality and community of those modest watering holes, a Times reporter has worked them into his coverage.
content: When I arrived in Rio de Janeiro, a colleague immediately invited me to a “dirty foot.” My reputation, it appeared, had preceded me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Sterlin Harjo Can Do a Lot More Than ‘Reservation Dogs’
description: The filmmaker directed “Love and Fury,” a Netflix documentary about Native American artists, before his hit Hulu series.
content: Sterlin Harjo has had a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Peloton’s Bumpy Ride
description: The company’s challenges are a warning for others as the pandemic enters a third year.
content: Peloton, the high-end exercise equipment maker, was one of the hottest stocks early in the coronavirus pandemic, gaining five times its value in 2020. But its struggles to hold onto all of those windfall gains — its shares are down more than 70 percent this year — show how challenging it is for stay-at-home stocks like Peloton and Zoom to adapt to the lifting of lockdowns, hybrid working setups and other habits taking shape in the third year of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Four people are arrested in India after a man leaves the country using a fake virus test result.
description: The man, a 66-year-old South African pharmaceutical executive, fled his quarantine hotel and was later confirmed to have the Omicron variant.
content: The police in the southern Indian state of Karnataka have arrested four people on suspicion of helping a South African man leave India with a fake negative coronavirus test report, officials said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
title: Jan. 6 Committee Recommends Contempt Charge for Meadows
description: The panel sent a criminal contempt of Congress referral to the full House, as the extent of Mark Meadows’s role in President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the election became clearer.
content: WASHINGTON — Mark Meadows, the last White House chief of staff for President Donald J. Trump, played a far more substantial role in plans to try to overturn the 2020 election than was previously known, and he was involved in failed efforts to get Mr. Trump to order the mob invading the Capitol on Jan. 6 to stand down, investigators for the House committee scrutinizing the attack have learned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: That Viral Harry Styles Cardigan Just Got Auctioned as an NFT
description: Jonathan Anderson, the designer who made the original sweater, explains how it happened and what's next.
content: The love affair between fashion and NFTs shows no sign of abating. The latest nonfungible token to get everyone tingling with excitement: a perfect 3-D digital replica of the patchwork JW Anderson cardigan that became a viral hit during the pandemic when Harry Styles wore it. Created with xydrobe, it sold at auction on Dec. 14 for two Ether (the cryptocurrency), or approximately $7,500.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: An Intimate Look at the Dangerous, Boom-and-Bust Lives of Oil Workers
description: In “Sea State,” Tabitha Lasley writes about the time she spent in Scotland investigating life on and around oil rigs.
content: Why is it so hard to capture a flattering picture of one’s breasts? Here are a few reasons posited by Tabitha Lasley, the author of “Sea State,” as she attempts a topless selfie: If one tilts the camera upward in hopes of producing a firm and youthful impression, one’s lower face may barge into the frame, accompanied by a more-than-desirable number of chins. If breasts are presented in profile, stomach proportions have to be considered. Taken from the front, with elbows pressed inward to slim the waist, breasts may acquire “the pendulous aspect of a nursing ape’s.” Lasley taps her phone’s camera button relentlessly, documenting each shift in pose, until, on her 94th try, she strikes the nude-selfie jackpot: an image that improves upon reality without veering into implausibility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: She Got the First Vaccine. Now It’s a Year Later.
description: Sandra Lindsay hopes she signaled that science and medicine can be trusted.
content: It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at two pandemic-related stories: First, we’ll catch up with the first person in the United States to receive a coronavirus vaccine — one year ago today. Then we’ll look at why New York City hasn’t regained jobs the way the rest of the country has.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: New York’s Top 10 New Restaurants of 2021
description: After a year that began with indoor dining banned in the city, our critic Pete Wells cherishes the places that celebrate sharing — and life.
content: “Eat every meal as if it were your last,” Nora Ephron once said, “because when the last one comes you probably won’t be hungry.” I’ve always appreciated the gallows humor of that remark, but its advice struck me as unwise. Every meal? I love you, Nora, but I’ve got school lunches to make in the morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: California regulators propose raising fees on owners of rooftop solar systems.
description: The plan was welcomed by the state’s electric utilities while a solar industry association leader called it a “disaster.”
content: California regulators on Monday proposed requiring people with rooftop solar panels to pay more of the costs of operating the electric grid, a plan that some supporters of clean energy argued could greatly reduce the incentive for new residential installations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coralie Kraft
title: Mackenzie Davis Catches Fire
description: In the new HBO Max series “Station Eleven,” Davis plays the lead as a tough but vulnerable survivor of a pandemic. She had ample experience to draw from.
content: “There’s no going back to the before,” the actress Mackenzie Davis said, lifting her head and peering intently at an approaching Rollerblader. It was a bright early fall day in Manhattan, and Davis reclined comfortably on a peeling park bench outside the Tompkins Square dog run in the East Village.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Across Latin America, the Holidays Mean It’s Time for Buñuelos
description: The sweet, fried dough is a common street food year-round, but the dessert is especially popular during the Christmas season.
content: When Viridiana Padilla Johnson was a little girl in the Mexican state of Sonora, Christmastime celebrations radiated out from her grandmother’s kitchen. That’s where she’d watch her prepare buñuelos, learning how to make the disks herself along the way. An accompanying piloncillo syrup, made with unrefined sugar, perfumed the space with the warm smells of clove and anise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Oil supply is expected to catch up to demand, offering relief on prices.
description: The International Energy Agency said that the key factor in its improved outlook was rising production in the United States, Canada and Brazil.
content: Oil production is on the verge of exceeding demand this month, potentially easing pressure on prices, the International Energy Agency said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: The 10 Best California Books of 2021
description: These new works of fiction and nonfiction vividly render the state’s past and present.
content: The end of 2021 is approaching, and with it comes the traditional slew of year-end lists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: It’s an Interactive Experience, Charlie Brown!
description: An adventure awaits visitors in Honolulu in “The Search for Snoopy,” starting in March.
content: “Peanuts” fans who have dreamed of visiting Snoopy’s red doghouse, Lucy’s therapy booth (only 5 cents!) or Charlie Brown’s classroom will have their chance next year, with an interactive experience in Honolulu called “The Search for Snoopy: A Peanuts Adventure.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reyhan Harmanci
title: The Welcome Return of the Run-In
description: Running into acquaintances used to be a routine annoyance. Now, it’s an unholy rush.
content: Last month, for the first time in two years, I went to a play. Afterward, on the street, I spotted an acquaintance and felt an unexpected wave of elation. A person whom I knew, hadn’t thought of in months, and did not make plans to see, stood in front of me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Dave Ramsey Fired Employee for Taking Covid Precautions, Suit Says
description: In his complaint, a former employee says the Tennessee radio broadcaster, an evangelical Christian who has built a personal finance empire, violated his religious rights.
content: The radio broadcaster and anti-debt crusader Dave Ramsey has been accused of firing an employee for wearing masks at the office and for wanting to work from home during the Covid-19 pandemic, according to a federal lawsuit filed this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Trends in Arctic Report Card: ‘Consistent, Alarming and Undeniable’
description: The changes happening at the top of the planet could unfold elsewhere in the years to come, scientists report.
content: Across the icy dome that crowns the Earth, rising temperatures are turning the tundra greener and more lush. Beavers are expanding their range. Garbage from passing ships is fouling the shores. Wildfires are scorching the once permanently frozen lands of Siberia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yewande Komolafe
title: Connecting With West Africa’s Plant-Based Past
description: Though meat dominates a number of the region’s most popular dishes, a growing number of cooks see adapting vegan and vegetarian diets as a way of embracing their heritage.
content: When she moved back to Lagos in 2010 after living and working abroad, Affiong Osuchukwu noticed that a lot of the Nigerian food she cherished had become meat-centric. Although the essence of the dishes hadn’t changed, they seemed, to her, to be meatier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: New Eye Drops Offer an Alternative to Reading Glasses
description: Vuity, a once-a-day treatment that can help users see up close without affecting their long-range vision, went on the market Thursday after being approved by the F.D.A. in October.
content: An eye drop that improves close-range vision could make misplaced reading glasses less of an inconvenience for many of the 128 million Americans who suffer from age-related deficits in near vision. Vuity, which became available by prescription on Thursday, is a once-a-day treatment that can help users see up close without affecting their long-range vision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘The Royal Tenenbaums’ at 20: When Wes Anderson Imagined New York
description: The film’s vision of the city is at once entirely made up and very real seeming, both dated and contemporary. But the movie couldn’t outrun current events.
content: Wes Anderson’s sprawling comedy-drama “The Royal Tenenbaums,” released 20 years ago this month, tells the story of a family of famed child geniuses, the disappointments and neuroses that define their lives as adults and the estranged father whose (feigned) illness brings them back together, under one roof in Upper Manhattan. It’s Anderson’s only film to date shot entirely in and around New York City, his sole entry in the canon of Gotham cinema, which was so formative to his youth in the Southwest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Todd Gregory and Roni Caryn Rabin
title: The Omicron variant’s rapid spread could soon lead to a wave, the C.D.C. warns.
description: In a call with state and local health officials, the agency warned of a possible surge peaking in January.
content: The proportion of coronavirus cases in the United States caused by the Omicron variant has increased sharply, and may portend a significant surge in infections as soon as next month, according to new data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: 10 Senate Races to Watch in 2022
description: Democrats have a razor-thin margin that could be upended with the loss of a single seat.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New York stopped taking applications for pandemic rent aid. Now it faces a lawsuit.
description: Tenant and housing groups are seeking to force the state to start accepting applications for pandemic rent relief again, arguing that closing the program left many struggling renters vulnerable to eviction.
content: Several tenant and housing groups in New York filed a lawsuit on Monday seeking to force the state to reopen its pandemic rent relief program, arguing that a recent decision to stop accepting applications for the aid has left thousands of struggling renters vulnerable to eviction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: Deals Reached on $14 Billion Airport and Rail Projects in New York City
description: Elected officials announced deals on funding of a new international terminal at Kennedy Airport and improvements to commuter train service.
content: Now that Congress has approved a massive increase in spending on infrastructure, three big transportation projects in New York City with a combined estimated cost of nearly $14 billion are back on track.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval, Tariro Mzezewa and Christine Hauser
title: Jail Officer Who Led Others to Safety Is Among the 74 Killed in Tornadoes
description: Families were mourning in several states after a swarm of tornadoes left a trail of destruction. “It’s almost crushing how it feels,” said Kentucky’s governor, Andy Beshear.
content: MAYFIELD, Ky. — Robert Daniel, a veteran corrections officer at the county jail, was keeping a watchful eye on seven inmates assigned to work at a Kentucky candle factory when the sirens went off, warning of an oncoming tornado.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Casa Dani, From a Celebrated Spanish Chef, Opens in Manhattan West
description: A new turn for Brasserie 8½, a bakery from Greg Baxtrom of Olmsted, and more restaurant news.
content: New York first met the Spanish chef Dani Garcia at Manzanilla on Park Avenue South. That was eight years ago. Since then, Dani Garcia, his restaurant in Marbella, Spain, picked up a third Michelin star (it’s now closed), and the chef formed his own company, Grupo Dani Garcia. Now, he has returned to New York and is on the marquee of Casa Dani in the Manhattan West complex, west of the Moynihan Train Hall. “What I’m doing at Casa Dani is not fine dining,” he said. “I want to showcase the culture of Spain, making it easy, fresh and fun, more like home cooking.” He said a great deal had changed since he was first in New York, especially the increasing availability of ingredients. His thinking has also changed, he said. “Twenty-five years of fine dining, which is more conceptual and less from the heart, is enough,” he said. What hasn’t changed is having Alberto Carballo, the chef de cuisine, at his side. A soaring 180-seat dining room, a sea of beige designed by David Rockwell, sits on a level below the bar and open kitchen. There are tapas; fried items like cod fritters; bigger portions (raciones), many with seafood; and rice and noodle specialties. There are also a few main dishes, including daurade and hanger steak, and even larger-format platters for the table like whole Spanish turbot. A section on the menu is devoted to fresh tuna prepared several ways, which Mr. Garcia considers to be representative of the soul of Spanish cooking. Near the entrance to Mr. Garcia’s restaurant, which he runs with Sam Nazarian, is his Pollo Verde, a casual spot in the Citizens NY food hall at the complex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In ‘Flying Over Sunset,’ Getting High With the Stars
description: A new musical imagines the all-singing, all-dancing LSD trips of Aldous Huxley, Clare Boothe Luce and Cary Grant.
content: To a perpetual square, nothing is as mystifying as another person’s high. Or so I learned in college, during the heyday of chemically induced inner journeys — and again at the Vivian Beaumont Theater the other night. Though sometimes mesmerizing, “Flying Over Sunset,” the new musical about LSD that opened there on Monday, is mostly bewildering, and further proof that transcendence can’t be shared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Jollimore
title: Famed for Fiction, Jim Harrison Was Also a Poet of Prodigious Appetites
description: Pleasure and mortality are the twin themes of Harrison’s mammoth “Complete Poems,” spanning his career from his 1965 debut to his 2016 death.
content: JIM HARRISONComplete PoemsEdited by Joseph Bednarik
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: This Is What Happens When Workers Don’t Control Their Own Lives
description: The disasters that struck in Kentucky and Illinois cannot be separated from the overall political economy of the United States.
content: For a vast majority of Americans, democracy ends when work hours begin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joey Roulette
title: Former Interns Say SpaceX Ignored Sexual Harassment
description: Some women at the company, founded by Elon Musk, described feelings of powerlessness and a failure by the company’s human resources office to discipline male employees.
content: Three women who interned at SpaceX said they faced sexual harassment and unwanted advances from other interns as well as men in more senior positions across a range of workplace incidents, some of which went without punishment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Pfizer’s Covid Pill
description: The company says it prevents severe illness.
content: A highly anticipated study of Pfizer’s Covid pill confirmed that it helps stave off severe disease, the company said. The pill also performed well against the highly mutated Omicron variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: Its Human Rights Record in Question, China Turns to an Old Friend
description: The International Olympic Committee’s professed neutrality has provided coverage for Beijing, which delivers big audiences and funding in exchange.
content: When China’s leaders came under pressure to answer questions about the health and whereabouts of Peng Shuai, the Chinese tennis star, they turned to a friendly face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Lawyers Clash Again Over Subpoena for Trump’s Financial Records
description: The long-running case dates back to an early 2019 House Oversight Committee demand to see years of the then-president’s financial data.
content: WASHINGTON — A lawyer for former President Donald J. Trump urged a federal appeals court to quash a congressional subpoena seeking years of financial records from his accounting firm, arguing on Monday that the demand is too broad and could open the door for lawmakers to routinely harass and intimidate future presidents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Why the World’s Astronomers Are Very, Very Anxious Right Now
description: The James Webb Space Telescope is endowed with the hopes and trepidations of a generation of astronomers.
content: What do astronomers eat for breakfast on the day that their $10 billion telescope launches into space? Their fingernails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Giulia Heyward
title: The U.S. Air Force dismisses 27 over vaccine refusals, a tiny fraction of its members.
description: They are the first members of a total U.S. military force of more than two million believed to be forced out over the shots.
content: The U.S. Air Force has dismissed 27 service members for refusing to get vaccinated against the coronavirus, a tiny fraction of its members but the first members of the military believed to be forced out over the shots
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Cornell University goes on high alert after finding evidence of the Omicron variant on campus.
description: The school moved final exams online, canceled a December graduation ceremony and sports events and barred most visitors from its campus in Ithaca, N.Y.
content: Cornell University canceled a ceremony for December graduates, closed libraries and took other restrictive measures on Tuesday after the school’s coronavirus testing lab found evidence of the Omicron variant in a number of students’ test specimens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Omicron Is a Dress Rehearsal for the Next Pandemic
description: America’s response to the variant highlights both how much progress we have made over the past two years — and how much work remains.
content: When scientists discovered the highly mutated Omicron variant of the coronavirus last month, it set off an eerily familiar chain of events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Shirley McBay, Pioneering Mathematician, Is Dead at 86
description: The first Black student to receive a doctorate from the University of Georgia, she devoted her life to advocating for diversity in science and math education.
content: Shirley McBay, who in 1966 became the first Black person to receive a doctorate from the University of Georgia, and who went on to be a leading voice for diversity in science and math education, died on Nov. 27 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Britain drops southern African nations from its ‘red list’ for quarantine restrictions.
description: With the Omicron variant already spreading, officials conclude they’ve lost the battle to prevent its entering Britain.
content: With new coronavirus cases surging at home, the British government on Tuesday lifted its special restrictions on travelers arriving from 11 African countries, ending measures it had adopted hoping to curb the spread of the Omicron variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘The Hand of God’ Review: A Portrait of the Cineaste as a Young Man
description: Paolo Sorrentino’s autobiographical drama about growing up in Naples is sensual, sad and occasionally sublime.
content: What good are movies? According to one line of thinking cited in “The Hand of God,” they are useless except as a “distraction from reality,” something we need because “reality is lousy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mireille Silcoff
title: What Can You Learn from a Celebrity Masterclass on Empathy?
description: Pharrell Williams is joined by a chorus of famous people whose lessons about feeling for others strangely highlight their personal achievements.
content: Each online course from Masterclass begins with the same introduction. Heels click purposefully into a room. A piano lid is confidently opened, a marble slab floured, a knife honed. Lighting pools warmly amid expensive-looking wood. Swells of music coalesce into momentary silence; something of quality is about to start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays, Dana Rubinstein and Katie Glueck
title: Adams, Wading Into Council Speaker Race, Puts Political Capital at Risk
description: After saying he would stay out of the race, Eric Adams, the incoming mayor, has sought to install an ally. It was unclear whether he would succeed.
content: When New York City’s mayor-elect, Eric Adams, said he was staying out of the combative race for City Council speaker, the declaration made sense: He still has the vast majority of his cabinet appointments to make, and an extraordinarily challenging job awaiting him in three weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Belarus Opposition Leader Is Sentenced to 18 Years in Prison
description: The activist Sergei Tikhanovsky planned to challenge the country’s authoritarian leader, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, in a presidential election last year. He was arrested before the vote and his wife stepped in.
content: MOSCOW — A court in Belarus on Tuesday convicted an opposition leader on charges of organizing mass unrest and inciting social hatred over his attempt to challenge the country’s authoritarian leader, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, in a presidential election last year. It sentenced him to 18 years in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mehrsa Baradaran and Jeremy Kress
title: Your Pocketbook Is Ruled by This Agency, and It’s in the Middle of a Huge Fight
description: The current chairwoman could effectively run out the clock on the president’s first term.
content: The last time you walked into a branch of your bank, you might have noticed a sign bearing the official seal of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the government agency that regulates and insures thousands of depository institutions. What you may have not realized, however, is that there is a bitter partisan battle brewing for control of the F.D.I.C. that may determine whether your bank survives, whether a financial crisis wipes out your savings and whether presidential elections matter for financial policymaking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: After a School Shooting, Should Parents Be Prosecuted?
description: A Michigan prosecutor hopes the strategy can prevent more school shootings. But some on both sides of the gun control debate are wary.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: For Aging New Yorkers, Help With Health Care
description: When a Holocaust survivor needed a dental procedure, nonprofit groups assisted. The challenges on a fixed income can be daunting.
content: Saveliy Kaplinsky had an annual tradition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: N.B.A. Says It Will ‘Follow the Science’ as Coronavirus Cases Rise
description: Outbreaks and exposures on multiple teams led the league this week to postpone games for the first time this season, with a series of marquee matchups looming.
content: For the first couple of months of the N.B.A. season, the league operated with something that approximated business as usual: full arenas and full rosters as teams adapted to the new normal of playing through the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Exhausted World Wonders: Will the Covid Era Ever End?
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, December 14, 2021.
content: “People are so exhausted their greatest fear is not so much a new variant but a new curfew.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: How Did Turkey’s Economy Go So Wrong?
description: Even before the pandemic, Turkey was trying to ward off financial meltdown. The crisis has accelerated as President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has doubled down on his unorthodox policies.
content: The signs of Turkey’s disastrous economy are all around. Long lines snake outside discounted bread kiosks. The prices of medicine, milk and toilet paper are soaring. Some gas stations have closed after exhausting their stock. Angry outbursts have erupted on the streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: Feed the Hungry? You’ll Need a Permit for That.
description: Newark, New Jersey’s largest city, is working on an ordinance that would restrict the practice of feeding homeless people who live on the street.
content: NEWARK — At dusk the converted school bus pulled up to the little park as it does every Friday evening, and a line began to form. A man with a clipboard made his way down the line taking names and asking questions: “You need any socks or hygiene kits tonight? Anything I can pray for?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Two years of pandemic despair.
content: After two years of zigzagging policy and roller coaster emotions, terrible loss and tantalizing false dawns, closing borders and intermittently shuttered schools, people’s resilience across the globe has dwindled. For their leaders, this poses a quandary: How can they impose yet more restrictions on a fragile, exhausted populace after so much forced separation?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: For Jazz Musicians in 2021, Two Was the Magic Number
description: A host of outstanding duet albums emphasized musicians not only collaborating but truly listening to each other.
content: The violinist and multimedia artist Laura Ortman stood onstage at the Stone earlier this month clad in a bejeweled paisley jacket with a bow under her arm. She welcomed the crowd with an interested smile, and explained that the music that evening would be “dedicated to distance.” After the set she spoke again, saying that throughout it she had been meditating on the feeling of “never being close enough.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Britain’s Omicron restrictions
description: And the verdict on Pfizer’s Covid pill.
content: During the summer, with virus cases on the wane, Britain embraced a live-and-let-live approach, casting off many virus restrictions on what became known as “freedom day.” Five months later, as Omicron doubles infections every two or three days, the country is reversing course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Windolf and John Koblin
title: Fox News Hosts Sent Texts to Meadows Urging Trump to Act as Jan. 6 Attack Unfolded
description: Afterward, on their shows, Laura Ingraham spread the false claim of antifa involvement, and Sean Hannity referred to the 2020 election as a “train wreck.”
content: Three prominent Fox News anchors sent concerned text messages on Jan. 6 to Mark Meadows, the last chief of staff for President Donald J. Trump, urging him to persuade the president to take the riot seriously and to make an effort to stop it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Reid
title: Let Them Eat (Wacky, Whimsical) Cake
description: From weddings to birthdays, fantastically imperfect cakes slathered in frosting, or that wobble and wiggle, are redefining the look of celebratory confections.
content: Adorned with dried Queen Anne’s lace, red clover flowers, bolted callaloo, dried onion flowers, fresh thyme and a fresh cabbage rose on top, the cake that baker Aimee France made for a recent wedding at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park looked as if it could have been decorated with flora she found while transporting it to the location.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Best Albums of 2021? Let’s Discuss.
description: Our critics spar over their year-end lists (and agree on Olivia Rodrigo and Tyler, the Creator) in a wrap-up of the year in LPs.
content: Olivia Rodrigo and Tyler, the Creator released the only albums that appeared on the 2021 year-end lists of all three pop music critics for The New York Times. Beyond that, there was a diverse bounty: Memphis rap, Colombian electronic folk, British spazz-rock, Atlanta soul, Georgia country-rap, Chicago jazz abstraction, California Technicolor rock and Adele.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Can We Make Our Granddaughter Give Up Her Scary Dog?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what terms we can attach to our plans to help loved ones — and more.
content: My granddaughter recently moved from her city apartment to our small town. She was having financial problems, and my husband and I decided to buy a small historic hotel in the hope that she could turn it into an artists’ retreat. She had always told us that it was one of her dreams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller and Tariro Mzezewa
title: They Said the Tornado Would Hit at 9:30. It Hit at 9:30.
description: Scientists have reached success rates of nearly 100 percent in predicting when and where violent tornadoes will strike. That hasn’t stopped people from being killed in the ferocious winds.
content: Morgan Jackson, a cashier at Casey’s General Store, a gas station in Mayfield, Ky., checked the weather all day Friday as her phone bleeped with loud alerts, friends and family called to compare notes and customers chatted incessantly about the tornadoes that were likely to head their way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Portrait of Abortion
description: And the Supreme Court’s two very different paths.
content: The Supreme Court seems all but certain to rewrite the country’s abortion laws when it rules in coming months on a case from Mississippi. But the real-world effects of that ruling will differ enormously depending on how far the justices go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Schoenfeld Walker and Lazaro Gamio
title: What It Takes to Understand a Variant
description: Science is unfolding in real time as researchers race to understand the new Omicron variant. Here’s a guide to those efforts, and when you can expect more answers.
content: Science is unfolding in real time as researchers race to understand the new Omicron variant. Here’s a guide to those efforts, and when you can expect more answers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: How much material from space enters the Earth’s atmosphere on an average day?
description: Earth is under attack from space dust.
content: Earth is under attack from space dust.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz, Claire Cain Miller and Quoctrung Bui
title: Who Gets Abortions in America?
description: The typical patient is already a mother; is poor; is unmarried and in her late 20s; and has some college education.
content: The typical patient is already a mother; is poor; is unmarried and in her late 20s; and has some college education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: After a Bumpy Ride, Airlines Prepare for a Busy Christmas
description: Airlines expect to carry many more people — and bags — over the holidays as demand recovers to nearly where it was before the pandemic.
content: Airlines expect to carry many more people — and bags — over the holidays as demand recovers to nearly where it was before the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz
title: If Roe Is Reversed, by the Numbers
description: The Supreme Court is considering overturning Roe v. Wade. Here’s how that could play out numerically.
content: The Supreme Court is considering overturning Roe v. Wade. Here’s how that could play out numerically.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur, Raymond Zhong, Aaron Krolik, Aliza Aufrichtig and Nailah Morgan
title: How Beijing Influences the Influencers
description: China’s government has supported foreign YouTubers who put a positive spin on its policies, in its latest effort to shape how the world sees it.
content: China’s government has supported foreign YouTubers who put a positive spin on its policies, in its latest effort to shape how the world sees it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Ultimate Amenity in a Pandemic: Santa Claus
description: Is it any surprise that places where it’s ‘Christmas all the time’ have been attracting a record number of buyers during the pandemic?
content: Is it any surprise that places where it’s ‘Christmas all the time’ have been attracting a record number of buyers during the pandemic?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Home-Fader-test
description: Home-Fader-test
content: Home-Fader-test
source.name: The New York Times

title: test fader
description: fader test
content: fader test
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Storyful
title: Winter Storm Brings Heavy Rain and Snow to California
description: Heavy snow created hazardous road conditions for drivers in parts of the Sierra Nevada.
content: Heavy snow created hazardous road conditions for drivers in parts of the Sierra Nevada.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is Biden’s Presidency a Disappointment?
description: Readers assess the Biden presidency. Also: Mark Meadows and Jan. 6; paying for abortions for women in need.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
